column4: clabledevil: i don't know the anser to your problem - but it sounds like theres an automatic shutdown program
shutdown is a command, you may want to try man shutdown for more info

cabledevil: there's a command you can use in terminal "shutdown", that i /think\ can be used to set up automatic shutdown times. you may want to try "man shutdown" to read the manual page on it. because there may be a way to reset, or UNset the shudown
I have never heard of automagic shutdown on a default install, though
netiher have i, but it's all i can think of
my default install didn't allow the floppy to be written to, i had to manually edit fstab, go figure...
how do you make it so it's not 'busy'...are there processes to kill or something?
close open files on the drive
for cd drives you can use the 'eject' command
thanks, i was trying to use top the day but it was greek to me...
you probably want to use lsof to show open files
you can grep for the mount point
awesome, didn't know about lsof either (thanks). lots of output, greps a good idea, i wonder if there are any switches to use too? <'man-ing' losf>
lsof /dev/hda1 or similar might be useful as well
gave lsof /dev/hd1 a shot, and i got an error message...about 'can't stat file system (ext 3)'...what's that about?
not sure. try sudo lsof, though
